1.0 Summary
The City of Scottsdale Wastewater Treatment Plant at 8787 E. Hualapai Drive, maintains approximately 40,000-70,000 lbs of Chlorine on its premises at all times for the purposes of Wastewater Treatment.  The Wastewater Treatment Plant is staffed and monitored 24-hours/day, 7 days/week.
  
The goal of the Process Safety Management/Risk Management Program (PSM/RMP) is to reduce the risk of accidental chemical releases that may result in injuries and/or incidents to the employees, public, environment and facilities/property.  The organization's management is committed to achieving and sustaining this goal.  The program complies with EPA Federal Regulation Part 68.150 through 68.190 (RMP) and the Arizona Division of Occupational Safety and Health Standard 29 CFR 1910.119 (PSM).

Since the facility start-up (~10 years), there's been one accidental release of chlorine (within the past 6 months), resulting in two injuries.   The release did not require an evacuation and during the event, there was no risk to the public, environment or facility equipment.  Subsequent incident investigation activities occurred to address root cause/causal factors.  Incident learning?s are being shared, with intent to standardize across similar processes within the City of Scottsdale in an effort to continuously improve our Prevention Program. 

Below is an overview of the Treatment Plant PSM/RMP Program components.

EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION
1.1 Specific means of promoting employee participation and actively consulting with employees on matters of process safety are as follows: 
1.1.1 Process Hazard Analysis - All hazard analyses will include a representative from affected personnel and associated organizations throughout the City of Scottsdale (Fire, etc).  The basis for selecting employees will be determined by their involvement with the covered process.  
1.1.2 Operating Procedures- The development of new operating procedures and the revision of existing procedures will involve th

e employees operating or maintaining the covered process.  
1.1.3 Training - Experienced employees will be directly involved in the development and periodic review of training materials and methods.  All employees will be given the opportunity to comment on the training program through direct comments or written course evaluations.   
1.1.4 Pre-Startup Safety Review - The pre-startup safety review team will consist of representatives from the technical operations disciplines, Safety, the contractors, and the construction organization, including at least one employee familiar with the covered process.  
1.1.5 Mechanical Integrity - The development of new operating procedures and the revision of existing procedures will involve the employees operating or maintaining the covered process.  Any concerns or deficiencies raised by employees will be investigated and, when applicable, written changes will be made to the mechanical integrity program.   
1.1.6 Management of Change - The management of change procedure pertains to the review of all proposed revisions to the site?s process systems, equipment, or operating procedures in order that these do not lead to an increased level of risk.  All levels of employees are involved in the change process, as it applies to the change. 
1.1.7 Incident Investigation ? All levels of employees will participate on teams investigating incidents related to the covered process.  The results of these investigations will be shared with all employees, when applicable/available.  
1.1.8 Emergency Response - All employees involved in the covered process shall be made aware of the requirements of the Emergency Processes and Response Requirements.  
1.1.9 Compliance Audit - During compliance audits, affected personnel will be interviewed to get feedback of their involvement and participation in the implementation of the PSM/RMP program and their accessibility to the documentation.  
1.1.10 Employee Access to Information - All employees will be gi

ven access to any and all information developed under the PSM/RMP Program.  The management will maintain hard copies of all information relating to the specific elements of the covered process, and most information is available via the City of Scottsdale Intranet.

PROCESS HAZARDS ANALYSIS
2.1- An initial process hazard analysis (hazard evaluation) is required on processes covered by this standard.  The following methodology shall be utilized to determine and evaluate the hazards of the process being analyzed:
2.1.1 What-If Checklist or an approved equivalent methodology.
2.2 - The process hazard analysis shall be performed by a team with generalized/diverse expertise, and the team shall include at least one employee who has experience and knowledge specific to the process being evaluated. Also, one member of the team must be knowledgeable in the specific process hazard analysis methodology being used.
2.3 - A written PHA document shall be issued and include recommendations, a written schedule of when these actions are to be completed, and owner.
2.4 - At least every five (5) years after the completion of the initial process hazard analysis, the process hazard analysis shall be updated and revalidated by a team to assure that the process hazard analysis is consistent with the current process.
2.5 - The City of Scottsdale shall retain process hazards analyses and updates or revalidations for each process, as well as the documented resolution of recommendations for the life of the process.

OPERATING PROCEDURES
3.0 Written operating procedures that provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities involved in each covered process consistent with the process safety information and shall address at least the following elements.  These shall be managed and maintained by the applicable System Owner.
- Initial Startup Procedures
- Normal Operation.
- Temporary Operation.
- Emergency Shutdown.
- Emergency Operations.
- Normal Shutdown.
- Startup after Turnaround o

r Emergency Shutdown.
3.1 - Operating procedures shall be updated based on corrective action resulting from incident investigations and revalidation of the Process Hazard Analysis.
3.2 - Operating procedures shall be reviewed annually.

TRAINING
4.0 The initial training program for the ?Covered Process? is recommended to include the following in the Qualified Operator training:
?site safety equipment
?proper use of personal protective safety equipment
?safety precautions
?hazards, first aid and chemical handling
?From the Operation/Maintenance Manual:
?system specific information
?operating procedures
?troubleshooting and maintenance
4.1 Refresher Training required every three years and documented.

CONTRACTORS
5.0 When selecting a contractor  that will perform maintenance or repair, turnaround, major renovation, or specialty work on or adjacent to a covered process, the selection lead shall obtain and evaluate information regarding the contract employer's safety performance and programs.

PRE-STARTUP REVIEW
6.0 Any covered process startup must follow a Pre-Startup Review, and include any supplemental startup documentation provided by the supplier, or identified system specific requirements.  This includes a startup after a system modification.  This is to ensure:
    Construction and equipment is installed in accordance with design specifications;
    Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate;
    Safety systems and controls are tested and functional

MECHANICAL INTEGRITY
7.0 Written maintenance and testing procedures are required for the following "Covered Process" equipment.  These shall be managed and maintained by the applicable System Owner.

PERMIT to WORK
8.0 All hot work operations conducted on or near a covered process shall utilize the City of Scottsdale's Hot Work Program.

MANAGEMENT of CHANGE
9.0 All changes to the design, operation, and maintenance of the covered process shall be communicated to all affected organiz

ations.

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION
10.0 Incident investigation shall be conducted immediately post-incident.  Subsequent follow-up to follow the City of Scottsdale's Risk Management policies.

11.0 EMERGENCY PLANNING and RESPONSE
11.1 The covered process shall fall under the site Emergency response and planning program and infrastructure.

COMPLIANCE AUDITS
12.0 A compliance focused self-assessment audit of the PSM/RMP Program shall be conducted at a minimum of every three years to verify that the procedures and practices developed under the standard are adequate and are being followed.
